addressleaf.section:
Copie of my l
re
to my L. T
re
r 22 Oc
t
95.

page.lettertext:
fol.87r
May it please your good L. After so muche deliberation,
as in my last unto your L.
e 19 of this moneth I
reported at large,
e
States
deputed
M
r
Barnevelt
and
M
r
Vanderwerke
, w
t
the Greffier of their
college, to acquaint me with
e tenor of 2 severall
l
res
, which they have written to her
Ma
tie
and
my LL. of
e Councel, tending onely to excuse
e
protracting of their answear to her Ma
ties
dem
a
des
to shewe their curiousnesse alwayes in observing
e Contract, to foresignifie
e dangers, if
e
people should be told that her Ma
tie
would
dissolve it, and to intreate her to have patience,
till their State will permitte, that they may
use a shorter course, and give her better con-
tentation. They required me withall with
a vehement kinde of speeche, That as I tendered
e advancement of her Hig
es
service, and
e
good correspondence betweene
e two contreys, and
as I knew their allegations to be true, and
unfained, and found in conversation a hard
conceat
e people had of this demande of resti-
tution, I should second their l
res
with others
of myne owne, and deale in
at behalf w
t
all
sinceritie and roundnesse, wherby her Hig
es
might forbeare from taking an extreme or ri-
gorous course against them. Wherunto
for an answear I signified againe,
at in all
at they desired, I had done my duetie throughly,
by my former advertisements, and had faithfully
delivered all their reasons to her Ma
tie
in everie
suche material point, as their l
res
made re-
monstrance: all w
ch
notwithstanding her Hig
es
could not finde, but if so be they would en-
devo
r
to persuade
e Generalitie, and therein
use their opportunities, w
t
at dexteritie and
wisedome, as they are wont in weightie causes
fol.87v
they might drawe them to
e paiment of some conve-
nient portion: Wherby perhaps she might be moved
not to presse them for a while to any further rem-
boursement, But when nothing at all is presen-
ted unto her,
considering her
long and chargeable succo
rs
, and
considering her present domestical necessities,
with other manifold occasions, of which they
had bin by me informed at full, and they of
themselves could make
e reckning well enough,
it could not choose but engender some notable
alienation. Moreover for my self I had
bin charged expressely, not to yeld or to hearken
to any dilatorie answear: for w
ch
they were not to
attend my conveyance of their l
res
, nor any other
office,
at might any way seeme to favor their pre-
ent resolution. Of that whi ch passed too and fro to
this effect and
e lyke, they made relation to their
college: who for ought I can perceave goe onward
with their purpose, to send away those l
res
, w
che
I thinke they will consigne to their Agent
M
r
Caron
. The
Councel of Estate
was very earnest-
ly bent to have sent unto her Ma
tie
some men
of good account, and
e States, I am persuaded,
had folowed
at counsaile, but that they stayed
their proceeding upon my prohibition. And thus
remaining uncertaine, w
at
course of further
dealing will be pleasing to her Ma
tie
I will at-
tend in
at behalf yo
r
L. good direction,
and
take my humble leave.
From
e Hage 22 Oct
r
95
.
